comments.body: The xrootd devs have already done this for the xrootd 3 libs when xrootd 4 came out; I let them know that this is a priority for OSG.

Made new builds with version 5.0.1 from SOFTWARE-4212. I tested the EL7 version in a local VM by enabling upcoming-minefield but adding the line {{exclude=gfal2*}} to the repo definition. I was able to install gfal2-plugin-xrootd from epel alongside xrootd 5.

I can't do an 'exclude' line in VMU tests so I will have to untag gfal2 from upcoming-development and upcoming-testing before I can run VMU tests against this.

|| Build || Tag ||
| [xrootd-5.0.1-1.1.osgup.el7|https://koji.chtc.wisc.edu/koji/buildinfo?buildID=13826] | osg-upcoming-el7-development |
| [xrootd-5.0.1-1.1.osgup.el8|https://koji.chtc.wisc.edu/koji/buildinfo?buildID=13827] | osg-upcoming-el8-development |
Go ahead and promote this to {{upcoming-testing}}, untag the {{gfal}} packages, and kick off the VMU tests.

*Promotions*
Promoted xrootd-5.0.1-1.1 to osg-upcoming-el*-testing
|| Build || Tag ||
| [xrootd-5.0.1-1.1.osgup.el7|https://koji.opensciencegrid.org/koji/buildinfo?buildID=13826] | osg-upcoming-el7-testing |
| [xrootd-5.0.1-1.1.osgup.el8|https://koji.opensciencegrid.org/koji/buildinfo?buildID=13827] | osg-upcoming-el8-testing |

VMU test runs are here; https://osg-sw-submit.chtc.wisc.edu/tests/20200819-1159/results.html

For some reason, the tests tried to pull in xrootd-scitokens from 3.5 instead of upcoming; I don't understand why.
There appears to be a newer version of {{xrootd-scitokens}} in 3.5 vs upcoming (1.2.2 vs 1.2.1). I’m surprised that Yum’s not smarter about this, though.

https://osg-sw-submit.chtc.wisc.edu/tests/20200820-1048/packages.html I think these are as good as I'm going to get.
I would ask to promote but it's already in upcoming testing. Permission to mark this ticket RFT?
The cleanup failures are a little concerning. Does {{yum uninstall}} really fail like that for the compat libs?

Not necessarily related to the cleanup failure, but I just noticed that the client compat libs ended up in both the xrootd-client-libs package and the xrootd-client-compat package (oops). I should probably fix that, though depending on yum's intelligence, it may make 4->5 upgrades easier...

I messed around with things in a VM and I'm fairly certain I'm fairly certain that the cleanup failures are caused by a bug in osg-test where it somehow skips a history event during cleanup -- for example, if the history events are 8, 9, 10, it skips doing {{yum history undo 10}} and just does {{yum history undo 9}}, which obviously fails.

The reason that _that_ happens is because I was a moron and forgot to convert to integers before sorting (so instead of {{\[8, 9, 10]}}, we get {{\["10", "8", "9"]}}). I'm guessing that I do more yum installs when building the EL8 image than the EL7 image, so the history numbers are higher. (d'oh)

https://osg-sw-submit.chtc.wisc.edu/tests/20200827-1503/packages.html <- awww yeah

I'll make the promotion request in SOFTWARE-4212.

*Promotions*
Promoted xrootd-5.0.1-1.3, xrootd-lcmaps-1.7.8-3 to osg-upcoming-el*-testing
|| Build || Tag ||
| [xrootd-5.0.1-1.3.osgup.el7|https://koji.opensciencegrid.org/koji/buildinfo?buildID=13846] | osg-upcoming-el7-testing |
| [xrootd-5.0.1-1.3.osgup.el8|https://koji.opensciencegrid.org/koji/buildinfo?buildID=13847] | osg-upcoming-el8-testing |
| [xrootd-lcmaps-1.7.8-3.osgup.el7|https://koji.opensciencegrid.org/koji/buildinfo?buildID=13851] | osg-upcoming-el7-testing |
| [xrootd-lcmaps-1.7.8-3.osgup.el8|https://koji.opensciencegrid.org/koji/buildinfo?buildID=13852] | osg-upcoming-el8-testing |

components.description: XRootD, related components, and SE metapackages for it.
components.name: xrootd

nonEditableReason.message: The Parent Link is only available to Jira Premium users.

fields.description:
The current EPEL version of gfal2 doesn't support XRootD 5 and this causes our tests to fail, along with WN client installs. If Michal isn't back from vacation, let's put one together ourselves containing the libs from XRootD 4 that are no longer shipped with XRootD 5. If Michal is back, work with him on it.

After promoting to testing, we should untag the gfal2 packages that we've built from upcoming-testing and upcoming-development.

fixVersions.description: xrootd-hdfs 2.1.8, osg-release 3.5-4; Upcoming: HTCondor 8.9.8, XRootD 5.0.1 and associated plugins

comments.body: The xrootd devs have already done this for the xrootd 3 libs when xrootd 4 came out; I let them know that this is a priority for OSG.

Made new builds with version 5.0.1 from SOFTWARE-4212 Closed . I tested the EL7 version in a local VM by enabling upcoming-minefield but adding the line exclude=gfal2* to the repo definition. I was able to install gfal2-plugin-xrootd from epel alongside xrootd 5.

I can't do an 'exclude' line in VMU tests so I will have to untag gfal2 from upcoming-development and upcoming-testing before I can run VMU tests against this.

VMU test runs are here; https://osg-sw-submit.chtc.wisc.edu/tests/20200819-1159/results.html

For some reason, the tests tried to pull in xrootd-scitokens from 3.5 instead of upcoming; I don't understand why.
There appears to be a newer version of xrootd-scitokens in 3.5 vs upcoming (1.2.2 vs 1.2.1). I’m surprised that Yum’s not smarter about this, though.

https://osg-sw-submit.chtc.wisc.edu/tests/20200820-1048/packages.html I think these are as good as I'm going to get.
I would ask to promote but it's already in upcoming testing. Permission to mark this ticket RFT?
The cleanup failures are a little concerning. Does yum uninstall really fail like that for the compat libs?

Not necessarily related to the cleanup failure, but I just noticed that the client compat libs ended up in both the xrootd-client-libs package and the xrootd-client-compat package (oops). I should probably fix that, though depending on yum's intelligence, it may make 4->5 upgrades easier...

I messed around with things in a VM and I'm fairly certain I'm fairly certain that the cleanup failures are caused by a bug in osg-test where it somehow skips a history event during cleanup – for example, if the history events are 8, 9, 10, it skips doing yum history undo 10 and just does yum history undo 9, which obviously fails.

The reason that that happens is because I was a moron and forgot to convert to integers before sorting (so instead of [8, 9, 10], we get ["10", "8", "9"]). I'm guessing that I do more yum installs when building the EL8 image than the EL7 image, so the history numbers are higher. (d'oh)

https://osg-sw-submit.chtc.wisc.edu/tests/20200827-1503/packages.html <- awww yeah

I'll make the promotion request in SOFTWARE-4212 Closed .
